review_title: Philanthropy went downhill with new leadership
pros: Great cause for their work overseas, opportunity to learn about different aspects of fundraising (major gifts, planned giving, corporate, etc.)
cons:
Leadership is absolutely horrible. I was one of 20 people who left in 1 year due to the nepotism and ageism. Very little support for career development and pathetic raises. You are also treated like a child if you ever question their decision (many people got shut down and told directly that because they were young, they didnt know what they were talking about). 
For a youth empowerment organization, this is horrendous and does not reflect the mission of the organization.
Many complaints to HR did nothing and these leaders are still there today.

review_title: Great donor care team but management isn't great!
job_title: Donor Care Representative in Toronto, ON
pros:
- All the donor care representatives were great people, always willing to lend a hand and very friendly.
- varied shifts are good for people who enjoy shift work - but don't join if you want a 9-5 Monday to Friday job.
- Ability to pick up extra shifts as pay is hourly not salaried.
cons:
- For the size of the department there were too many managers - who enjoyed going out for frequent smoke breaks whilst micromanaging the team.
- Pay/contract instability isn't worth the stress of the job
- Outbound dialing is very tedious, you spend all your work day listening to dialing tones.
- No benefits with short term contracts

pros:
Benefits are offered and additional offerings for mental health have been added since the pandemic. The company also offers retirement matching and sometimes end of year bonuses. 

Option to continue to work from home, but the organization places emphasis on employees having to come into work at least once a week. 

Strong mindset of knowing we're all working to help the world. Organizational goals and KPIs are straightforward and easy to grasp.
cons:
Extremely difficult to move up in the organization, even when there is more than enough credibility and proof to back up a pay raise and title change. Most lower paying jobs do not have promotional tracks to follow. There seems to be hesitancy in creating new jobs and the organization would rather hire people into short-term contracts, outsource as much as possible and/or expect employees to do the jobs of multiple people. Expect to be told "you will be wearing a lot of hats". 

Incredible ageism amongst colleagues, especially at the executive level. Staff are consistently told that executives want our feedback, but then never include those at the bottom, which skews younger, in their focus groups. Instead, you will be prompted to fill out a survey asking if you have feedback – do not worry, they will most definitely NOT implement any of the feedback and continue emailing you about surveys. It's the never ending survey loop, with responses like, "we will chat about that in a month" and "I'll get back to you on that (never gets back to you, even with multiple follow up emails). When feedback is addressed, executives and higher-ups speak down to employees and act like the feedback responses are silly and not worth answering in full. How can a company ask for so much feedback but then decide it's not worth their time to figure out solutions? Even when half the time amazing and thoughtful solutions are provided by staff themselves? 

This organization loves buzz words. Be prepared to hear lots of them like, "you should be willing to take on responsibility and leadership roles within their team" when you are in a non-managerial position (this basically translates to "we want a manager for the salary of a non-managerial employee") and "we’re not a company, we’re a family". These and more are thrown around a lot, but realistically the work environment is more often than not a toxic one, filled with cliques, guilt trips, crossing professional boundaries (people will message and email you at 11pm and on weekends) and favouritism. 

Huge turn over! Most employees leave after 2–4 years due to a variety of reasons. In three years, large turn over happened in three different departments, with anywhere from 3–7 people leaving all at once. This puts a massive amount of strain on the remaining employees to fill in those gaps, as filling those positions usually takes months. 

Lastly, in 2017/2018, a few employees tried to create a DE&I committee, and was reluctantly shut down at the exec. level. For years, people have tried to create a more welcoming place of work, to be shot down again and again. It was only after 2020, during the height of the BLM Movement, that the company decided to jump in and create a DE&I committee. Why didn't the company feel the need to create one years earlier when requested and promoted by staff? I also find it strange that the majority of lower paying jobs are usually held by BIPOC employees, where as stated earlier, almost have little to no room to grow and move up the corporate ladder.

review_title: My Experience at Plan International Canada
job_title: Donor Support Representative in Toronto, ON
pros:
-Working for an organization that works to empower the human rights of girls and women.
-Working for a cause that is meaningful and soul feeding.
-Diversity amongst employees.
-The chance to grow, depending on which department you're working in.
cons:
-Nepotism is rampant
-Employees in the donor support department were mostly young girls, new graduates signed on with temporary contracts - not in a position to raise any issues about management or work as their contracts would not be renewed.
-Those that were friendly with management would be renewed and/or promoted.
-It's truly a pity that in an organization that has such lofty ideals and is working to improve the conditions of women's rights has a department with in which these ideals are undermined on a daily basis.

review_title: Great mission, great people, huge transformation underway
pros: A high growth org in an overall diminishing market. We’ve spent the past 2-3 years transforming from a small mom and pop mindset with the warmth but with the limitations that entails - including highly incestuous leadership, to a high functioning midsize enterprise with a clear view of our future and what we need to do to achieve it.  Building on a really strong core in key areas (Eg international programs), the  company has put in place nearly all new leadership - from the Board on down - and are starting to see the fruits of this effort. It’s not for the feint of heart - but if you like being on the the leading edge of any industry, and if you like working for a ceo with both passion and expertise, you will love working here
cons: Transition is tough.  We’ve lost some good people who have decided the challenge of change is not for them.  Also - it’s BUSY! This is not the place to ‘retire to’ in order to ‘give back’.
